awd_titl_txt: American Geophysical Union (AGU) Chapman Conference on Particle Dynamics in the Earth's Radiation Belts; Cascais, Portugal; March 4-9, 2018
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the travel for early career scientists to the AGU Chapman Conference on "Particle Dynamics in the Earth's Radiation Belts" in Cascias, Portugal March 4-9, 2018. This meeting brings together world leaders in space plasma phenomena from South Korea, Japan, Europe and the USA and provides significant opportunity for students to participate in sessions. The meeting is largely focused on the variability of the space plasma environment and enables a collaborative, workshop-style environment for discussions. This is timely and relevant to the nation's space weather efforts. Understanding of the environment is important for understanding how space weather events evolve.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In March of 2018, radiation belt scientists descended upon the beautiful, seaside town of Cascais, Portugal, to discuss and debate the current state of the field. The week-long meeting, Particle Dynamics in the Earth’s Radiation Belts, was organized under the auspices of the American Geophysical Union (AGU) Chapman Conference program, which encourages innovative research through small, topical meetings designed to permit in-depth exploration of specialized subjects in a manner not possible at large meetings. The conference was well attended, with roughly 100 attendees representing fourteen countries. There was a strong contingent (~25%) of students and early career researchers who were supported by generous travel grants from the United States National Science Foundation (NSF) and the VarSITI program of the Scientific Committee On Solar-Terrestrial Physics (SCOSTEP). Of particular note, more than half of the invited speakers were from underrepresented groups. The conference website is available here, along with the full scientific program, which includes .pdf files of nearly all of the oral and poster presentations that were given at the conference. A special issue of the Journal of Geophysical Research – Space Physics is currently being planned as well.

 

NSF's funding support allowing young researchers (students, postdocs, and early career scientists) to attend the small, workshop-style meeting provided them with valuable experiences that they may not have had otherwise. Their participation in the meeting also advanced their educational and scientific development, which in turn is contributing to the development of a globally competitive STEM workforce. Moreover, the Conference Conveners made a concerted effort to engage and emphasize early career researchers at the conference, with six of the 16 invited speakers being young scientists. In addition, the Conference Conveners aimed for gender equality among the conference participants, exemplified by having eight females as invited speakers. Finally, and as a broader benefit, the advances made at the conference will benefit the US and improve its national security, given the hazards posed by the radiation belts to the space-based technologies on which society depends.

Modified by: Pranoti Asher
